title: 'Objection to discharge' and 'Motion to lift automatic stay' are they the same?
question: I did not file an 'objection to discharge' but I did file a 'motion to lift automatic stay' and the court has set a hearing date for the motion I filed. Is it a must to file an 'objection to discharge'? I guess they are both targeting 'the debt not to be discharged'. Is there any difference between this two? At this moment what shall I do? Am I on the right track?
answers: A motion to lift automatic stay allows a creditor to take action on the debt, like a foreclosure. An objection to discharge is where the creditor is disputing whether the debt should be dischargeable or not. It depends on what you are trying to accomplish in the case. To answer your question more fully, as to whether you are on the right track, we would need more information regarding what you are trying to accomplish.

The two are very different. The motion to lift automatic stay allows a lawsuit to be filed to liquidate a claim, foreclose on a security interest, evict a tenant, etc. If money is awarded, it is part of the bankruptcy estate.

An objection to discharge, if successful, prevents the debtor from receiving a discharge of debts in bankruptcy. It is usually brought in connection with a fraud committed by the debtor.

While a Motion for Relief can be filed at any time, an Objection to Discharge has a deadline for filing.
If what you are trying to do is prevent the debtor from getting rid of the debt he owes you, you need to file your Objection to Discharge within the proper time period or lose the ability to do so.
